questions.text: A 65-year-old man with chronic leukaemia presents with symptoms of gout. He was given Allopurinol. How does Allopurinol prevent the accumulation of uric acid?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mechanism of Allopurinol:

  • Allopurinol is a structural analog of hypoxanthine.
  • It competitively inhibits xanthine oxidase, the enzyme responsible for:
    1. Hypoxanthine → Xanthine
    2. Xanthine → Uric acid
  • This leads to decreased production of uric acid, preventing hyperuricemia and gout.
  • It also causes accumulation of hypoxanthine and xanthine, which are more soluble and can be reused for purine synthesis via the salvage pathway.

Explanation of other options:

By increasing uric acid metabolism (Option A): Incorrect. Allopurinol does not increase the metabolism or excretion of uric acid. Instead, it reduces the formation of uric acid by inhibiting xanthine oxidase.

By inhibiting purine synthesis (Option B): Incorrect. Allopurinol does not directly inhibit purine synthesis. However, when xanthine and hypoxanthine accumulate, they are recycled via HGPRT in the purine salvage pathway, which provides negative feedback on de novo purine synthesis. This effect is secondary, not the primary mechanism.

By inhibiting pyrimidine synthesis (Option C): Incorrect. Allopurinol has no role in pyrimidine metabolism. Pyrimidine synthesis (UMP, CTP, TTP) is an entirely different pathway and is unaffected by xanthine oxidase inhibition.

choices.text: Further joint aspiration with depomedrone injection

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is on furosemide for leg oedema. He presents with a painful, swollen knee. His temperature is 38 °C and he has a white cell count of 12 x 10^9/L and CRP of 120 mg/l. Uric acid is 10 mg/dl (High). A joint aspirate reveals pus cells and negatively birefringent crystals with polarized light. After treatment with NSAIDs for 48 hours, he has not improved, and the swelling persists. There are no organisms cultured from the joint aspirate or blood cultures. What is the best course of action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is acute gout rather than septic arthritis, as evidenced by:

  • Presence of negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals in the joint aspirate (pathognomonic for gout).
  • No organisms grew on culture despite fever and inflammatory markers.
  • Furosemide (loop diuretics) is a known risk factor for gout because it increases uric acid levels.

Even though CRP and WCC are raised (which also happens in septic arthritis), the absence of organisms on culture and the presence of urate crystals confirms gout.

Management:

  • First-line: NSAIDs or colchicine.
  • If no improvement after 48 hours, intra-articular corticosteroid injection (e.g., depomedrone) after aspirating the joint is recommended.
  • Long-term urate-lowering drugs (like allopurinol) are introduced after the acute attack has resolved, not during an active flare.

Explanation of other options:

Allopurinol (Option A): Should NOT be started during an acute attack as it can worsen or prolong the flare. It is used only after the acute episode subsides.

MRI to look for osteomyelitis (Option B): Not indicated because there is no evidence of infection (negative cultures and classical gout crystals).

Arthroscopy and washout (Option C): Indicated only when septic arthritis is confirmed or strongly suspected, not in crystal-proven gout.

questions.text: A 54-year-old dark-skinned man presents with lethargy, polyuria, polydipsia, and stiffness of the hands. He has evidence of an arthropathy affecting the 2nd & 3rd metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands. X-ray confirms evidence of degenerative disease at these sites. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is classic for hereditary haemochromatosis:

Key clues:

  • Dark skin pigmentation → “Bronze diabetes” from iron deposition in skin and pancreas.
  • Polyuria, polydipsia → Diabetes mellitus due to pancreatic involvement.
  • MCP joint involvement (2nd and 3rd MCP joints) → Characteristic arthropathy of haemochromatosis, sometimes associated with chondrocalcinosis/pseudogout.
  • Radiology: Early degenerative changes at these specific MCP joints is very typical.

Pathology:

  • Excessive iron deposition in multiple organs:
    • Skin → Hyperpigmentation (“bronzing”)
    • Pancreas → Diabetes mellitus
    • Joints → Arthropathy, particularly 2nd and 3rd MCP joints (hook-like osteophytes on X-ray)
    • Heart and liver → Cardiomyopathy and cirrhosis

Key learning point:

  • Arthropathy and hypogonadism do not improve with iron depletion (phlebotomy).

Explanation of other options:

Behçet's syndrome (Option A): Presents with oral/genital ulcers, uveitis, and thrombosis. Arthropathy is not characteristically localized to the 2nd/3rd MCP joints and does not explain the skin pigmentation or diabetes.

Amyloidosis (Option C): Can cause multisystem disease and carpal tunnel syndrome, but does not preferentially affect the 2nd and 3rd MCP joints or produce bronze skin pigmentation.

Reiter's syndrome (Reactive arthritis) (Option C): Triad of urethritis, arthritis (especially lower limb/ankle/knee), and conjunctivitis. Does not produce skin bronzing, diabetes, or this specific joint pattern.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman has a swollen, erythematous knee joint. Aspiration of the joint was performed. Microscopy showed positively birefringent crystals. What are the crystals composed of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of pseudogout (Calcium Pyrophosphate Deposition Disease – CPPD).

Key diagnostic clues:

  • Joint: Most commonly involves the knee.
  • Synovial fluid crystals:
    • Positively birefringent under polarized light.
    • Shape: Rhomboid or rod-shaped crystals (not needle-shaped).
  • Contrast with Gout:

Factors and Conditions Associated with Calcium Pyrophosphate Crystal Deposition Disease

  • Aging
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Postmeniscectomy or joint trauma
  • Familial-genetic
  • Endocrine-metabolic conditions:
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism
    • Hemochromatosis
    • Hypophosphatasia
    • Hypomagnesemia
      • Certain drugs: thiazides and loop diuretics, potentially proton pump inhibitors
      • Malabsorption
      • Gitelman’s syndrome
  • Gout
  • X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets
  • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

Explanation of other options

Calcium carbonate (Option A): Calcium carbonate deposition is not a recognized cause of crystal-induced arthritis. It may deposit in soft tissues in some metabolic conditions, but does not produce the classic positively birefringent rhomboid crystals seen in pseudogout.

Magnesium sulphate (Option B): Magnesium salts do not deposit in joints to cause crystalline arthritis. Hypomagnesemia can be a risk factor for calcium pyrophosphate deposition, but magnesium crystals themselves are not the cause of arthritis.

Urate (Option C): Urate crystals (monosodium urate) cause gout, not pseudogout. They are needle-shaped, negatively birefringent under polarized light microscopy. In this question, the crystals were positively birefringent, so this rules out gout.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with an acute monoarthritis of the left knee. Gout is confirmed following joint aspiration and examination of fluid under polarised light microscopy. He had also undergone endoscopy 3 weeks earlier because of indigestion, which confirmed a duodenal ulcer. Which one of the following is the best treatment for the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has acute gout confirmed on joint aspiration.
  • However, he also has a recent duodenal ulcer, which makes the use of NSAIDs (including indomethacin and COX-2 inhibitors like celecoxib) contraindicated due to the high risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and ulcer worsening.
  • Intra-articular corticosteroid injection is therefore the safest and most effective option for rapid control of inflammation and pain in a large joint such as the knee.
  • Allopurinol is not used in the acute phase, as starting urate-lowering therapy during an acute attack can worsen or prolong it.

Explanation of other options:

Allopurinol (Option A): Indicated for chronic urate-lowering therapy, not for the acute phase. Starting during an acute flare may precipitate or exacerbate gout attacks.

Indomethacin and Lansoprazole (Option C): NSAIDs are a first-line treatment for acute gout, but are contraindicated in this patient due to a recent peptic ulcer. A PPI (lansoprazole) reduces acid, but does not eliminate the bleeding risk.

Celecoxib and Lansoprazole (Option B): Celecoxib (COX-2 inhibitor) also carries GI and cardiovascular risks. It is contraindicated during active peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man develops sudden-onset severe pain in his right big toe. On examination, he has swelling of the metacarpophalangeal joint of his right hallux. The surrounding skin is erythematous. It is tender to touch. Initial investigations reveal a raised white cell count and an elevated CRP. What should be done to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with acute monoarthritis of the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint (podagra), which is classic for acute gout.
  • However, other causes like septic arthritis and hemarthrosis must be ruled out, as their presentations can be similar and require different treatments.
  • Joint aspiration with synovial fluid analysis is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis:
    • Polarized light microscopy will show needle-shaped, negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals in gout.
    • It also allows Gram staining and culture to rule out septic arthritis, which is essential because infection can coexist with gout.

Acute Gout involving the left foot

Explanation of other options:

MRI of the toe (Option A): Useful for osteomyelitis or soft tissue pathology, but not diagnostic for gout. It is not the first-line investigation in acute monoarthritis.

Serum uric acid (Option B): Not reliable during an acute attack: uric acid levels may be normal or low due to urate shifting into the joint. Elevated levels are nonspecific and cannot confirm a diagnosis.

Serum rheumatoid factor (Option C): Used in suspected rheumatoid arthritis, which presents with a chronic, symmetric, polyarticular pattern—not acute monoarthritis.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is on treatment for chronic heart failure with diuretics. He has a previous history of asthma. He presents with a sudden onset of pain and swelling of the metatarsophalangeal joint of his right big toe. Aspiration of the joint demonstrates crystals of monosodium urate. What is the recommended treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has acute gout confirmed by joint aspiration showing monosodium urate crystals.
  • First-line treatments for acute gout are NSAIDs, colchicine, or corticosteroids.
    • NSAIDs (including COX-2 inhibitors) are contraindicated in asthma as they can precipitate bronchospasm.
    • Colchicine is safe and effective in this setting when given early.
  • Colchicine acts by inhibiting microtubule polymerization, reducing neutrophil chemotaxis and inflammation.

Explanation of other options:

Aspirin (Option A): Not recommended: low-dose aspirin can decrease uric acid excretion, worsening gout; high doses may cause other side effects.

NSAIDs (e.g., indomethacin) (Option C): Effective in gout but contraindicated in patients with asthma, heart failure, and those on diuretics due to risks of bronchospasm and fluid retention.

COX-2 inhibitors (e.g., celecoxib) (Option D): These also pose a risk of bronchospasm in aspirin-sensitive asthma and have cardiovascular risks, so not preferred here.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with acute stiffness, swelling of his knees and ankles, and a painful rash on his legs. The ESR was 107 mm/hour. Chest X-ray showed hilar lymphadenopathy bilaterally. What is the likely progression of the arthralgia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This presentation is typical of acute sarcoidosis (Löfgren's syndrome):
    • Triad:
      • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray
      • Erythema nodosum (painful nodular rash on shins)
      • Symmetrical acute oligoarthritis, typically of the ankles and knees
    • ESR is usually high.
  • Natural history:
    • The arthritis in Löfgren’s syndrome is self-limiting.
    • It typically resolves spontaneously over 6–8 weeks without leaving joint damage.
  • Treatment:
    • Symptomatic relief with NSAIDs; corticosteroids are reserved for severe systemic involvement.
    • Prognosis: Excellent; chronic arthritis is uncommon.

Explanation of other options:

Chronic arthritis (Option A): Rare in Löfgren’s syndrome. Sarcoid arthritis is usually acute and self-limiting.

Septic arthritis (Option B): Would present with fever, a single hot swollen joint, and positive joint aspirate cultures—not with hilar lymphadenopathy and erythema nodosum.

Improvement only with steroids (Option C): While steroids may be used if symptoms are severe, most cases improve without steroids.

questions.text:
A 64 year old man presents has recently developed an acutely painful right knee. On examination, he had a temperature of 37.2°C a hot and swollen right knee. His white cell count which was raised at 14 x 10^9/L. A knee X ray showed reduced joint space and chondrocalcinosis. Under the polarised microscope, there were neutrophils +++ and some blue rhomboidal crystals under parallel polarised light. Culture of aspirated fluid showed no growth.
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture is typical of pseudogout.

Calcification of the articular cartilage would be consistent and the culture results exclude septic arthritis. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the presence of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in joint fluid demonstrating a positive birefringence under polarised light.

Calcium pyrophosphate crystals

questions.text: A 71-year-old man developed acute monoarthritis of his right ankle on the second postoperative day following an elective inguinal hernia repair. He was on a diuretic for hypertension. On examination, his temperature was 38°C. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The acute onset of monoarthritis in the postoperative period, with risk factors such as diuretic use, strongly suggests gout.
  • Surgery, fasting, and dehydration can trigger a gout flare due to increased uric acid concentration and crystal precipitation.
  • The typical presentation: sudden swelling, erythema, and pain in a single joint (ankle, big toe).

Risk factors for gout:

  • Obesity and insulin resistance syndrome
  • Metabolic factors such as diet and alcohol
  • Genetic predisposition
  • Medications like diuretics and low-dose aspirin
  • Cardiovascular and renal conditions

Triggers for gout attacks:

  • Metabolic triggers such as purine-rich food and alcohol
  • Diuresis (e.g., after surgery or with diuretics)
  • Rapid changes in urate levels (for example, after starting urate-lowering therapy)
  • Local trauma
  • Medical illnesses such as heart failure and hypoxia

Explanation of other options:

Acute rheumatoid arthritis (Option A): Usually presents as a chronic, symmetric polyarthritis, not as an isolated acute monoarthritis.

Pseudogout (Option C): More commonly affects knees and wrists and is associated with calcium pyrophosphate crystals (positive birefringence).

Septic arthritis (Option D): Always a concern post-op, but in this case, there’s a clear risk factor for gout, and there are no systemic signs of sepsis (but aspiration must still be done to rule out infection).

questions.text: A 44-year-old male attends for a routine medical and is in good health. Examination was normal, but investigations revealed that he has a serum urate concentration of 9.2 mg/dl (4.2-7.5). Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has asymptomatic hyperuricemia (high uric acid without gout symptoms).
  • No treatment with urate-lowering drugs is indicated unless there are symptoms like gout attacks, urate nephropathy, or tophi.
  • First-line management:
    • Reduce alcohol intake, especially beer/spirits.
    • Avoid purine-rich foods (red meat, seafood).
    • Encourage weight loss and regular exercise.
    • Increase hydration.

Explanation of other options:

Allopurinol (Option B): Used for chronic urate lowering in recurrent gout, tophi, or urate nephropathy, not in asymptomatic cases.

Colchicine (Option C): Used for acute gout flares or prophylaxis when starting urate-lowering therapy.

Diclofenac (NSAID) (Option D): Used in acute gout attacks, not for asymptomatic hyperuricemia.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man has a painful, swollen right knee and difficulty in walking for three days.He had two self-limiting episodes of severe pain and swelling in the right big toe last year. He drinks 26 cans of beer/week.
On examination, his temperature is 36.8 C. The right knee is red, swollen, warm and tender and has restricted movement.
The knee aspirate shows no organisms on Gram stain, plenty of leucocytes, and negatively birefringent crystals on polarised light microscopy.
The results of recent blood tests are:
Hb 12.3 g/dl(13.0 - 18.0 g/dL)
WBC 14.3 x10^9/μl(4 - 11 x 10^9/L)
Neutrophils 88%(40-75%)
Platelet 340 x 10^9/L (150 - 400 x 10^9/L)
Urea, electrolytes and creatinine: Normal
ESR 79 mm/hr(0 - 15 mm/1st hr)
Uric acid 11 mg/dl
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Monosodium urate crystals are needle-shaped and are negatively birefringent. Therefore, this patient has acute gout.

He has several risk factors for gout, including

Age more than 40 years

Male gender

High alcohol consumption (more than 21 units for men, more than 14 units for women).

Pseudogout is caused by intra-articular shedding of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate

(CPPD) crystals. CPPD crystals are rhomboid and show a weak positive birefringence on polarised light microscopy. Pseudogout is common at the knee but rarely leads to podagra.

There is no history of recent infections to suggest reactive arthritis.

Septic arthritis of the knee is less likely as the Gram stain is negative.

Osteoarthritis of the knee usually presents as chronic mechanical joint pain.

choices.text: Send joint fluid for microscopy and culture

questions.text: A 47 year old man has a renal transplant. He presents with a hot swollen ankle on the left and fevers. The symptoms have been present for 2 days. What should be done?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acute monoarthritis with fever should raise the suspicion of septic arthritis, especially in immunosuppressed patients.

questions.text: What is the optimal target for a uric acid-lowering agent in gout?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The goal of urate-lowering therapy (ULT) in gout is to reduce serum urate levels to <6 mg/dL, and in patients with tophi or severe disease, sometimes even <5 mg/dL.

Why?

  • When serum uric acid is kept below 6 mg/dL, monosodium urate (MSU) crystals dissolve, preventing new crystal formation and promoting resolution of existing tophi.
  • Maintaining urate levels above 6.8 mg/dL leads to MSU crystallization and recurrent flares.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a condition associated with pseudo-gout?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A minority of patients with CPPD arthropathy have metabolic abnormalities or hereditary CPPD. As such, the presence of CPPD arthritis in individuals aged <50 years should lead to consideration of these metabolic disorders and inherited forms of disease, including those identified in a variety of ethnic groups. Included among endocrine-metabolic conditions are hyperparathyroidism, hemochromatosis, hypophosphatasia, and hypomagnesemia.
